Convergence of Update Aware Device Scheduling for Federated Learning at the Wireless Edge

Mohammad Mohammadi Amiri, Deniz Gündüz, Sanjeev R. Kulkarni,
H. Vincent Poor M. Mohammadi Amiri, S. R. Kulkarni, and H. V. Poor are with the Department of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, USA (e-mail: {mamiri, kulkarni, poor}@princeton.edu).D. Gündüz is with the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2AZ, U.K. (e-mail: d.gunduz@imperial.ac.uk).
Abstract

We study federated learning (FL) at the wireless edge, where power-limited devices with local datasets collaboratively train a joint model with the help of a remote parameter server (PS). We assume that the devices are connected to the PS through a bandwidth-limited shared wireless channel. At each iteration of FL, a subset of the devices are scheduled to transmit their local model updates to the PS over orthogonal channel resources, while each participating device must compress its model update to accommodate to its link capacity. We design novel scheduling and resource allocation policies that decide on the subset of the devices to transmit at each round, and how the resources should be allocated among the participating devices, not only based on their channel conditions, but also on the significance of their local model updates. We then establish convergence of a wireless FL algorithm with device scheduling, where devices have limited capacity to convey their messages. The results of numerical experiments show that the proposed scheduling policy, based on both the channel conditions and the significance of the local model updates, provides a better long-term performance than scheduling policies based only on either of the two metrics individually. Furthermore, we observe that when the data is independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) across devices, selecting a single device at each round provides the best performance, while when the data distribution is non-i.i.d., scheduling multiple devices at each round improves the performance. This observation is verified by the convergence result, which shows that the number of scheduled devices should increase for a less diverse and more biased data distribution.00footnotetext: This work was supported in part by the U.S. National Science Foundation under Grant CCF-0939370, and by the European Research Council (ERC) Starting Grant BEACON (grant agreement no. 677854).

I Introduction

Devices at the wireless network edge generate a huge amount of data that can be exploited to make sense of the state of a system or to predict its future states. Internet-of-things (IoT) devices, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), or extended reality (XR) technologies are prime examples, where data from multiple sensors must be continuously collected and processed. Many machine learning (ML) algorithms have been developed to exploit these massive datasets, but most current ML solutions focus on centralized algorithms, where a cloud server collects all the data to train a powerful model. However, offloading such massive amounts of data from the edge devices to the could server is often not feasible due to latency, bandwidth, or power constraints, or not allowed due to privacy concerns. A more desirable and practically viable approach is federated learning (FL), which enables ML at the wireless edge while the data never leaves the edge devices.

FL utilizes the computational capabilities of edge devices to process their local datasets and collaboratively train a learning model with the help of a parameter server (PS) collecting the local model updates from the devices [1]. Due to unreliable links from the edge devices to the PS with limited energy and bandwidth, it is essential to develop distributed learning techniques with limited communication requirements [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]. However, most of the existing works on communication-efficient FL ignore the physical layer characteristics, and consider perfect rate-limited links between the devices and the PS.

There have been few recent studies on FL taking into account the physical layer aspects of the wireless network from the devices to the PS. In [8], optimization over batch size and communication resources is proposed to speed up FL over wireless networks. FL over a Gaussian multiple access channel (MAC) with limited bandwidth is studied in [9], and novel digital and analog communication approaches have been proposed for the transmissions from the devices. While gradient compression followed by digital channel coding is employed for the former, the latter analog approach benefits from the superposition property of the wireless channel by transmitting the gradients in an analog form. Bandwidth efficiency is achieved in [9] by sparsification of the gradients and random linear projection. In [10], FL over broadband wireless fading MAC is studied, where analog transmission is combined with power control, and the devices perform channel inversion with the full knowledge of channel state information (CSI) to align their transmissions at the PS. In [11, 12], the bandwidth-efficient analog communication technique in [10] is combined with power control over a bandwidth-limited fading MAC, significantly reducing the communication load. Beamforming techniques at a multi-antenna PS for increasing the number of participating devices and overcoming the lack of CSI at the devices are introduced in [13] and [14], respectively. In [15], resource allocation across devices for FL over wireless channels is formulated as an optimization problem aiming to minimize the learning empirical loss function. Frequency of participation of the devices is introduced as a device scheduling metric in [16]. Also, a device scheduling policy for FL over wireless channels is studied in [17] to minimize the training delay. In [18] the authors study resource allocation for FL over wireless networks aiming to minimize the total energy consumption, and in [19] performance analysis of FL under different scheduling policies, including random scheduling, round-robin scheduling and scheduling based on the link qualities of devices, is provided. A channel aware quantization technique is proposed in [20] for digital transmission of the gradients over a Gaussian MAC with limited link capacities. Also, in [21] the authors develop a digital transmission utilizing the over-the-air aggregation feature of the wireless MAC from the devices to the PS.

In this paper, we build upon our previous work [22], and consider FL with digital transmission from the edge devices to the PS over a block fading wireless network with limited power and bandwidth resources. We design novel device scheduling and resource allocation techniques in order to select the devices that send their model updates at each iteration, and to allocate the limited wireless resources among the participating devices to perform orthogonal (interference-free) transmission. Specifically, we take into account the channel conditions and the significance of the local model updates at the devices for device scheduling to make sure that the channel resources are allocated to the devices with both important messages and sufficient-quality link capacity to convey their messages. Next we establish a convergence result for FL with device scheduling, where each participating device can only transmit a limited number of bits imposed by its channel capacity. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first convergence result evaluating the performance of FL as a function of the number of scheduled devices at each round, as well as the number of bits each participating device can transmit, which reduces with the number of participating devices. The authors in [23] develop a convergence result for FL with device scheduling, however the assumption is that devices can communicate with the PS over an interference-and error-free shared link with unlimited capacity. Numerical results illustrate the advantages of considering both the channel conditions and the local model updates at the devices for device scheduling over scheduling based on either of the two metrics individually. Experiments on MNIST dataset illustrate that allocating all the resources to a single device offers the best performance when the data is independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) across the devices, while scheduling more devices provides the best performance when data distribution is non-i.i.d.. The convergence result corroborates this observation. Modelling the asymmetry in the data distribution across devices by an increase in the variance of the local gradients, we observe that the convergence speed increases withe the number of scheduled devices when the variance of the gradients is large, while scheduling a single device provides the best performance when the variance is limited.

II-A FL System

In FL, each device performs multiple stochastic gradient descent (SGD) updates to minimize an empirical loss function with respect to its local dataset based on a globally consistent model parameter vector received from the PS. Let ℬmsubscriptℬ𝑚\mathcal{B}_{m} denote the local dataset at device m𝑚m, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M], with |ℬm|=Bsubscriptℬ𝑚𝐵\left|\mathcal{B}_{m}\right|=B. The loss function at device m𝑚m is given by

Fm​(𝜽)=1B​∑𝒖∈ℬmf​(𝜽,𝒖),m∈[M],formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑚𝜽1𝐵subscript𝒖subscriptℬ𝑚𝑓𝜽𝒖𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\displaystyle F_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)=\frac{1}{B}\sum\nolimits_{\boldsymbol{u}\in\mathcal{B}_{m}}f\left(\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{u}\right),\quad m\in[M], (2)

where f​(𝜽,𝒖)𝑓𝜽𝒖f\left(\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{u}\right) is an empirical loss function defined by the learning task and quantifies the loss of model 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} at sample 𝒖𝒖\boldsymbol{u}. During the t𝑡t-th global iteration, t=0,1,…𝑡01…t=0,1,\dots, having received global model parameter vector 𝜽​(t)𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}(t) from the PS, device m𝑚m performs a τ𝜏\tau-step local SGD, for some τ∈ℕ𝜏ℕ\tau\in\mathbb{N}. The i𝑖i-th step of local SGD for the t𝑡t-th global iteration at device m𝑚m, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M], corresponds to the following update:

We further denote the model parameter vector after the τ𝜏\tau-th local update at device m𝑚m by 𝜽m​(t+1)subscript𝜽𝑚𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t+1), i.e., 𝜽m​(t+1)=𝜽mτ+1​(t)subscript𝜽𝑚𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑚𝜏1𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t+1)=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}^{\tau+1}(t), m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M].

Each device conveys its local model estimate after τ𝜏\tau local steps to the PS, which updates the global model parameter vector 𝜽​(t+1)𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}(t+1) by averaging these results

𝜽​(t+1)=1M​∑m=1M𝜽m​(t+1).𝜽𝑡11𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝜽𝑚𝑡1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}(t+1)=\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t+1). (4)

This updated vector is then shared with the devices for further computations until convergence. Having defined the local model update at device m𝑚m as

Δ​𝜽m​(t)≜𝜽m​(t+1)−𝜽​(t),m∈[M],formulae-sequence≜Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡subscript𝜽𝑚𝑡1𝜽𝑡𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\displaystyle\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\triangleq\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t+1)-\boldsymbol{\theta}(t),\quad m\in[M], (5)

the update in (4) corresponds to

𝜽​(t+1)=𝜽​(t)+1M​∑m=1MΔ​𝜽m​(t).𝜽𝑡1𝜽𝑡1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}(t+1)=\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)+\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t). (6)

Thus, the PS requires model updates estimated at the devices to update the global model parameter vector.

When FL is implemented over a shared wireless medium, it is not reasonable to expect all the devices to be able to convey their model updates to the PS reliably, due to power and bandwidth constraints. When the available channel resources are shared between the devices, each device would be allocated only a limited bandwidth, and the amount of information that can be conveyed to the PS can be further limited due to fading. Hence, it is reasonable to schedule only a subset of the devices at each iteration so that the scheduled devices can convey their model updates with sufficient quality and reliability [12, 16, 17, 19].

In this paper, we consider scheduling a K𝐾K-element subset of the devices, denoted by ℳ​(t)⊂[M]ℳ𝑡delimited-[]𝑀\mathcal{M}(t)\subset[M], |ℳ​(t)|=Kℳ𝑡𝐾\left|\mathcal{M}(t)\right|=K, at each global iteration step t𝑡t, for the most efficient utilization of the power and bandwidth resources. The PS determines the set of scheduled devices, and informs them for transmission at each round. Accordingly, the PS updates the global model parameter vector based on the received local model updates from only the scheduled devices as follows:

𝜽​(t+1)=𝜽​(t)+1K​∑m∈ℳ​(t)Δ​𝜽m​(t).𝜽𝑡1𝜽𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑚ℳ𝑡Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}(t+1)=\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)+\frac{1}{K}\sum\nolimits_{m\in\mathcal{M}(t)}\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t). (7)

II-B Wireless Medium

We consider a wireless medium with limited bandwidth from the devices to the PS to transmit the local model updates Δ​𝜽m​(t)∈ℝdΔsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M]. We assume a single-carrier block fading wireless channel with n𝑛n symbols (time slots) using TDMA for transmission from the devices to the PS111The single-carrier assumption is for ease of presentation, and the results in this paper can be extended to multi-carrier systems.. We denote the length-n𝑛n input to the channel at device m𝑚m by 𝒙m​(t)∈ℂnsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡superscriptℂ𝑛\boldsymbol{x}_{m}(t)\in\mathbb{C}^{n}, where 𝒙m​(t)=𝟎nsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡subscript0𝑛\boldsymbol{x}_{m}(t)=\boldsymbol{0}_{n}, if m∉ℳ​(t)𝑚ℳ𝑡m\notin\mathcal{M}(t). We assume that, at each iteration step, CSI for all the uplink channels is known by the PS, while each device knows its own CSI. The channel input of device m𝑚m at the t𝑡t-th iteration is a function of the scheduling policy, channel gain hm​(t)subscriptℎ𝑚𝑡h_{m}(t), local dataset ℬmsubscriptℬ𝑚\mathcal{B}_{m}, and Δ​𝜽m​(t)Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t), m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. For a total of T𝑇T global iterations, we impose the following average transmit power constraint on device m𝑚m:

The PS instead uses an estimate of 1K​∑m∈ℳ​(t)Δ​𝜽m​(t)1𝐾subscript𝑚ℳ𝑡Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡\frac{1}{K}\sum\nolimits_{m\in\mathcal{M}(t)}\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t) upon receiving the noisy observation 𝒚​(t)𝒚𝑡\boldsymbol{y}(t) from the bandwidth-limited wireless medium to update the global model parameter vector, which is then shared among the devices through an error-free shared link for further computations.

We focus on digital transmissions from the devices to the PS, where each scheduled device employs data compression followed by channel coding to transmit its local model updates. We design various scheduling policies, and perform bandwidth allocation among the scheduled devices to have interference-free communication from the participating devices to the PS. In this digital approach, we assume capacity-achieving channel codes are employed by the devices, while the model updates are quantized at a resolution afforded by the channel capacity to guarantee their reliable transmission to the PS.

At each model update stage, device m𝑚m is allocated nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m} distinct time slots, such that ∑m=1Mnm=nsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚𝑛\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}n_{m}=n, where nm=0subscript𝑛𝑚0n_{m}=0, if m∉ℳ​(t)𝑚ℳ𝑡m\notin\mathcal{M}(t). For large enough nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m}, we assume that the Shannon capacity at device m𝑚m can be achieved; that is, the total amount of information that can be conveyed from device m𝑚m to the PS is given by Rm​(t)=nm​Cm​(t)subscript𝑅𝑚𝑡subscript𝑛𝑚subscript𝐶𝑚𝑡R_{m}(t)=n_{m}C_{m}(t), where Cm​(t)≜log2⁡(1+|hm​(t)|2​Pm​(t)/σ2)≜subscript𝐶𝑚𝑡subscript21superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡2subscript𝑃𝑚𝑡superscript𝜎2C_{m}(t)\triangleq\log_{2}\left(1+\left|h_{m}(t)\right|^{2}P_{m}(t)/\sigma^{2}\right) and Pm​(t)≜𝔼​[‖𝒙mn​(t)‖22]≜subscript𝑃𝑚𝑡𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑛𝑚𝑡22P_{m}(t)\triangleq\mathbb{E}\left[||\boldsymbol{x}^{n}_{m}(t)||^{2}_{2}\right], m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M].

III Digital SGD (D-SGD) Quantization Scheme

Here we present the data compression scheme employed by the devices for digital transmission over the wireless channel. We utilize the technique introduced in [24], and extended in [9] for FL over a bandwidth-limited wireless medium.

It is worth noting that, at global iteration t𝑡t, device m𝑚m intends to transmit Δ​𝜽m​(t)Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t), computed after the τ𝜏\tau-step SGD algorithm, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. For this purpose, it first quantizes Δ​𝜽m​(t)Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t) by setting all but the largest qm​(t)subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}(t) and the smallest qm​(t)subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}(t) entries to zero (in practice, we typically have qm​(t)≪dmuch-less-thansubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡𝑑q_{m}(t)\ll d). It then computes the average of the positive and negative entries denoted by qm+​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{+}(t) and qm−​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{-}(t), respectively. If qm+​(t)≥|qm−​(t)|superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{+}(t)\geq\left|q_{m}^{-}(t)\right|, it sets all the negative entries to zero and all the positive entries to qm+​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{+}(t), and vice versa, if qm+​(t)<|qm−​(t)|superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{+}(t)<\left|q_{m}^{-}(t)\right|. We denote the resultant quantized vector with qm​(t)subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}(t) nonzero entries at device m𝑚m by Δ​𝜽^m​(qm​(t))Δsubscript^𝜽𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}\left(q_{m}(t)\right), m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. To transmit Δ​𝜽^m​(qm​(t))Δsubscript^𝜽𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}\left(q_{m}(t)\right), device m𝑚m requires 32 bits representing the real value qm+​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{+}(t) or qm−​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{-}(t) plus 1 bit for its sign, and no more than log2⁡(dqm​(t))subscript2binomial𝑑subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡\log_{2}\binom{d}{q_{m}(t)} bits representing the locations of the nonzero entries, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. Thus, device m𝑚m needs to transmit a total of

rm​(qm​(t))=log2⁡(dqm​(t))+33​ bits,m∈[M].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡subscript2binomial𝑑subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡33 bits𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\displaystyle r_{m}\left(q_{m}(t)\right)=\log_{2}\dbinom{d}{q_{m}(t)}+33\mbox{ bits},\quad m\in[M]. (9)

The D-SGD quantization scheme at device m𝑚m is characterized by qm​(t)subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}(t), and represented by D-SGD​(qm​(t))D-SGDsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡{\mbox{D-SGD}\left(q_{m}(t)\right)} resulting in Δ​𝜽^m​(qm​(t))Δsubscript^𝜽𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}\left(q_{m}(t)\right), m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. The value of qm​(t)subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}(t) is a design parameter that is determined for different scheduling policies, described in the next section, to satisfy the capacity limitation of transmission from device m𝑚m to the PS, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M].

IV Device Scheduling Policies

In FL, the goal is typically to schedule as many devices as possible at each iteration [10]; however, when the updates are conveyed to the PS over a shared wireless medium with limited bandwidth, having more devices scheduled at each iteration means that each device is allocated fewer resources, and as a result, contributes to the learning task with less accurate information. The goal is to identify the set of scheduled devices at each iteration that results in the best performance.

After receiving 𝜽​(t)𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}(t) from the PS, all the devices perform the τ𝜏\tau-step SGD algorithm as in (3). However, only K≤M𝐾𝑀K\leq M devices in ℳ​(t)ℳ𝑡\mathcal{M}(t) are scheduled for transmission at iteration t𝑡t, and the PS updates the global model parameter vector as follows:

𝜽​(t+1)=𝜽​(t)+1K​∑m∈ℳ​(t)Δ​𝜽^m​(qm​(t)).𝜽𝑡1𝜽𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑚ℳ𝑡Δsubscript^𝜽𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}(t+1)=\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)+\frac{1}{K}\sum\nolimits_{m\in\mathcal{M}(t)}\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}(q_{m}(t)). (10)

We take into account the channel conditions and the significance of the local model updates at the devices as the scheduling metrics. We study four different scheduling policies, namely the best channel (BC), best l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm (BN2), best channel-best l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm (BC-BN2), and best l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm-channel (BN2-C) schemes, which we explain below.

Due to the natural symmetry of the considered model across the devices, both in terms of the channel statistics and the local model updates, it is reasonable to assume that the probability of scheduling each device will be the same222We will indeed see below that this assumption holds for all four scheduling policies considered in this paper., given by K/M𝐾𝑀K/M. Hence, the average transmit power constraint can be rewritten as follows:

KM​T​∑t=1TPm​(t)≤P¯,∀m∈[M].formulae-sequence𝐾𝑀𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑃𝑚𝑡¯𝑃for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\displaystyle\frac{K}{MT}\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}P_{m}(t)\leq\bar{P},\quad\forall m\in[M]. (11)

For simplicity, we assume a fixed transmission power over time for the scheduled devices, Pm​(t)=M​P¯/Ksubscript𝑃𝑚𝑡𝑀¯𝑃𝐾P_{m}(t)=M\bar{P}/K, ∀m∈ℳ​(t)for-all𝑚ℳ𝑡\forall m\in\mathcal{M}(t), ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t.

IV-A BC Scheduling Policy

The BC policy schedules devices based only on their channel gains. This generalizes the approach studied in [12], where only a single device is scheduled based on the channel conditions. With BC, the PS does not require any information about the model updates at the devices, and it schedules K𝐾K devices with the highest channel gain magnitudes; that is,

ℳ​(t)=max[K]⁡{|h1​(t)|,…,|hM​(t)|}.ℳ𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝐾subscriptℎ1𝑡…subscriptℎ𝑀𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{M}(t)={\max}_{[K]}\left\{\left|h_{1}(t)\right|,...,\left|h_{M}(t)\right|\right\}. (12)

Having no knowledge about the model updates at the devices, the PS allocates the bandwidth so that the scheduled devices can each transmit the same number of bits. Given ℳ​(t)={m1,…,mK}ℳ𝑡subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝐾\mathcal{M}(t)=\{m_{1},...,m_{K}\}, we want

nm1​Cm1​(t)=nm2subscript𝑛subscript𝑚1subscript𝐶subscript𝑚1𝑡subscript𝑛subscript𝑚2\displaystyle n_{m_{1}}C_{m_{1}}(t)=n_{m_{2}} Cm2​(t)=⋯=nmK​CmK​(t),subscript𝐶subscript𝑚2𝑡⋯subscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝐾subscript𝐶subscript𝑚𝐾𝑡\displaystyle C_{m_{2}}(t)=\cdots=n_{m_{K}}C_{m_{K}}(t), (13)

which, having ∑k=1Knmk=nsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑘𝑛\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}n_{m_{k}}=n, results in

nmk=∏i=1,i≠kKCmi​(t)∑j=1K∏i=1,i≠jKCmj​(t)​n,k∈[K].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscriptproductformulae-sequence𝑖1𝑖𝑘𝐾subscript𝐶subscript𝑚𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾superscriptsubscriptproductformulae-sequence𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝐾subscript𝐶subscript𝑚𝑗𝑡𝑛𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\displaystyle n_{m_{k}}=\frac{\prod_{i=1,i\neq k}^{K}C_{m_{i}}(t)}{\sum_{j=1}^{K}\prod_{i=1,i\neq j}^{K}C_{m_{j}}(t)}n,\quad k\in[K]. (14)

After the above bandwidth allocation scheme, device mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} performs quantization D-SGD(qmk​(t))subscript𝑞subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡(q_{m_{k}}(t)), with qmk​(t)subscript𝑞subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡q_{m_{k}}(t) set as the largest integer satisfying rm​(qmk​(t))≤nmk​Cmk​(t)subscript𝑟𝑚subscript𝑞subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡subscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝐶subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡r_{m}\left(q_{m_{k}}(t)\right)\leq n_{m_{k}}C_{m_{k}}(t), k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], and transmits the quantized bits to the PS over the time slots allocated to it.

IV-B BN2 Scheduling Policy

With BN2, the scheduling decision depends only on the significance of the model updates at the devices captured by the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of the model update, ‖Δ​𝜽m​(t)‖2subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡2\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2}. Transmissions take place in two phases, where in the first phase, having computed Δ​𝜽m​(t)Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t), device m𝑚m sends ‖Δ​𝜽m​(t)‖2subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡2\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2} reliably to the PS, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M]. The PS then schedules K𝐾K devices with the largest ‖Δ​𝜽m​(t)‖2subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡2\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2} values, i.e.,

ℳ​(t)=max[K]⁡{‖Δ​𝜽1​(t)‖2,…,‖Δ​𝜽M​(t)‖2}.ℳ𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝐾subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽1𝑡2…subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽𝑀𝑡2\displaystyle\mathcal{M}(t)={\max}_{[K]}\left\{\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}(t)\right\|_{2},...,\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{M}(t)\right\|_{2}\right\}. (15)

nmi​Cmi​(t)nmj​Cmj​(t)=‖Δ​𝜽mi​(t)‖2‖Δ​𝜽mj​(t)‖2.subscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝐶subscript𝑚𝑖𝑡subscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑗subscript𝐶subscript𝑚𝑗𝑡subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽subscript𝑚𝑖𝑡2subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽subscript𝑚𝑗𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{n_{m_{i}}C_{m_{i}}(t)}{n_{m_{j}}C_{m_{j}}(t)}=\frac{\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m_{i}}(t)\right\|_{2}}{\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m_{j}}(t)\right\|_{2}}. IV-C BC-BN2 Scheduling Policy

BC-BN2 generalizes BC and BN2 by taking into account both the channel conditions and the significance of the model updates at the devices. The PS first identifies Kcsubscript𝐾𝑐K_{c} devices with the best channel conditions, for some K≤Kc≤M𝐾subscript𝐾𝑐𝑀K\leq K_{c}\leq M. Then, among these Kcsubscript𝐾𝑐K_{c} devices K𝐾K with the most significant model updates are scheduled. Formally, the PS first selects the best Kcsubscript𝐾𝑐K_{c} devices according to their channel states as follows:

ℳc​(t)≜max[Kc]⁡{|h1​(t)|,…,|hM​(t)|}.≜subscriptℳ𝑐𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐾𝑐subscriptℎ1𝑡…subscriptℎ𝑀𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{M}_{c}(t)\triangleq{\max}_{[K_{c}]}\left\{\left|h_{1}(t)\right|,...,\left|h_{M}(t)\right|\right\}. (18)

Only these selected Kcsubscript𝐾𝑐K_{c} devices share ‖Δ​𝜽m​(t)‖2subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡2\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2} with the PS, which schedules K𝐾K devices among them as follows:

ℳ​(t)=max[K]⁡{‖Δ​𝜽m​(t)‖2,∀m∈ℳc​(t)}.ℳ𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝐾subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡2for-all𝑚subscriptℳ𝑐𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{M}(t)={\max}_{[K]}\left\{\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2},\forall m\in\mathcal{M}_{c}(t)\right\}. (19)

Having known ‖Δ​𝜽mk​(t)‖2,∀mk∈ℳ​(t)subscriptnormΔsubscript𝜽subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡2for-allsubscript𝑚𝑘ℳ𝑡\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m_{k}}(t)\right\|_{2},\forall m_{k}\in\mathcal{M}(t), we follow the same bandwidth allocation scheme as BN2. Thus, device mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k}, sends Δ​𝜽^mk​(qmk​(t))=D-SGD​(qmk​(t))Δsubscript^𝜽subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝑞subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡D-SGDsubscript𝑞subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m_{k}}\left(q_{m_{k}}(t)\right)=\mbox{D-SGD}\left(q_{m_{k}}(t)\right) to the PS, where qmk​(t)subscript𝑞subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡q_{m_{k}}(t) is set as the largest integer that satisfies rm​(qmk​(t))≤nmk​Cmk​(t)subscript𝑟𝑚subscript𝑞subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡subscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝐶subscript𝑚𝑘𝑡r_{m}\left(q_{m_{k}}(t)\right)\leq n_{m_{k}}C_{m_{k}}(t), k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], where nmksubscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑘n_{m_{k}} is given in (17).

We highlight that BC-BN2 for Kc=Ksubscript𝐾𝑐𝐾K_{c}=K and Kc=Msubscript𝐾𝑐𝑀K_{c}=M corresponds to BC and BN2, respectively.

IV-D BN2-C Scheduling Policy

With BN2-C, each device performs the D-SGD quantization scheme assuming the availability of all the bandwidth to itself, and finds the resultant quantized vector, whose l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm is sent to the PS, based on which it schedules the devices. To be more precise, device m𝑚m calculates the D-SGD quantization parameter, denoted by qm∗​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}^{*}(t), satisfying rm​(qm∗​(t))≤Cm​(t)subscript𝑟𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑚𝑡subscript𝐶𝑚𝑡r_{m}\left(q^{*}_{m}(t)\right)\leq C_{m}(t), ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M], based on which it computes Δ​𝜽^m​(qm∗​(t))=D-SGD​(qm∗​(t))Δsubscript^𝜽𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑚𝑡D-SGDsubscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑚𝑡\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}\left(q^{*}_{m}(t)\right)=\mbox{D-SGD}\left(q^{*}_{m}(t)\right); it then shares ‖Δ​𝜽^m​(qm∗​(t))‖2subscriptnormΔsubscript^𝜽𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑚𝑡2||\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}\left(q^{*}_{m}(t)\right)||_{2} with the PS. The PS schedules the devices with the best estimated l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm after quantization:

ℳ​(t)=max[K]⁡{‖Δ​𝜽^1​(q1∗​(t))‖2,…,‖Δ​𝜽^M​(qM∗​(t))‖2},ℳ𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝐾subscriptnormΔsubscript^𝜽1subscriptsuperscript𝑞1𝑡2…subscriptnormΔsubscript^𝜽𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑀𝑡2\displaystyle\mathcal{M}(t)={\max}_{[K]}\left\{||\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}\left(q^{*}_{1}(t)\right)||_{2},...,||\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{M}\left(q^{*}_{M}(t)\right)||_{2}\right\}, (20)

and, given mi,mj∈ℳ​(t)subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚𝑗ℳ𝑡m_{i},m_{j}\in\mathcal{M}(t), allocates the bandwidth to the scheduled devices such that

With ∑k=1Knmk=nsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑘𝑛\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}n_{m_{k}}=n, it follows that, for k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K],

Scheduled device m𝑚m performs the D-SGD(qm​(t))subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡(q_{m}(t)) quantization scheme, where qm​(t)subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q_{m}(t) is set as the largest integer satisfying rm​(qm​(t))≤nm​Cm​(t)subscript𝑟𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡subscript𝑛𝑚subscript𝐶𝑚𝑡r_{m}\left(q_{m}(t)\right)\leq n_{m}C_{m}(t), with nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m} given in (22), ∀m∈ℳ​(t)for-all𝑚ℳ𝑡\forall m\in\mathcal{M}(t).

Remark 1.

We highlight that BN2-C intertwines the channel conditions and the significance of local model updates to schedule the devices. Unlike BN2 and BC-BN2, where ‖Δ​𝛉m​(t)‖2subscriptnormΔsubscript𝛉𝑚𝑡2\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2} is directly used for scheduling, BN2-C utilizes the output of the D-SGD quantization scheme, ‖Δ​𝛉^m​(qm∗​(t))‖2subscriptnormΔsubscript^𝛉𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑚𝑡2||\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}\left(q^{*}_{m}(t)\right)||_{2}, for scheduling, where qm∗​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑚𝑡q^{*}_{m}(t) is a function of the channel gain. This novel technique comes with a computational cost at the devices due to the extra computation of Δ​𝛉^m​(qm∗​(t))Δsubscript^𝛉𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑚𝑡\Delta\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}\left(q^{*}_{m}(t)\right). On the other hand, BC requires the smallest computational overhead at the devices. In this work, we do not study the computational complexity at the devices, and the main goal is to utilize the limited communication resources efficiently.

V Convergence Analysis

Here we provide a convergence analysis for the FL over wireless networks with device scheduling, where the participating devices cannot transmit their local model updates in entirety due to the resource limitations and unreliable wireless links. For the convergence proof, we consider a slightly different quantization technique than the D-SGD quantization scheme, and we show that the gap between the expected loss function and the minimum loss function approaches zero for large enough T𝑇T. We first present the preliminaries and assumptions, and then the convergence result, whose proof is provided in the Appendix.

V-A Preliminaries

We define the optimal solution as

𝜽∗≜arg​min𝜽F​(𝜽),≜superscript𝜽subscript𝜽𝐹𝜽\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\triangleq\arg\mathop{\min}\limits_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}F(\boldsymbol{\theta}), (23)

and the minimum loss as F∗≜F​(𝜽∗)≜superscript𝐹𝐹superscript𝜽F^{*}\triangleq F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}). We also denote the minimum value of Fm​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑚⋅F_{m}(\cdot), the loss function at device m𝑚m, by Fm∗superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑚F_{m}^{*}, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. We then define

Γ≜F∗−1M​∑m=1MFm∗,≜Γsuperscript𝐹1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑚\displaystyle\Gamma\triangleq F^{*}-\frac{1}{M}\sum\limits_{m=1}^{M}F^{*}_{m}, (24)

where Γ≥0Γ0\Gamma\geq 0, and its magnitude indicates the bias in the data distribution across devices. For i.i.d. data distribution, given enough number of local data samples, B𝐵B, ΓΓ\Gamma approaches zero.

For the simplicity of the convergence analysis, we consider ηmi​(t)=η​(t)superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑚𝑖𝑡𝜂𝑡\eta_{m}^{i}(t)=\eta(t), ∀m,ifor-all𝑚𝑖\forall m,i. Thus, the i𝑖i-th step local SGD at device m𝑚m is given by

𝜽mi+1​(t)=𝜽mi​(t)−η​(t)​∇Fm​(𝜽mi​(t),ξmi​(t)),i∈[τ],m∈[M],superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑖1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑖𝑡𝜂𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑚𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝜏𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}^{i+1}(t)=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}^{i}(t)-\eta(t)\nabla F_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}^{i}(t),\xi_{m}^{i}(t)\right),\quad\mbox{$i\in[\tau]$},\mbox{$m\in[M]$}, (25)

where 𝔼ξ​[∇Fm​(𝜽​(t),ξm​(t))]=∇Fm​(𝜽​(t))subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑚𝜽𝑡subscript𝜉𝑚𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑚𝜽𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\xi}\left[\nabla F_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}(t),\xi_{m}(t)\right)\right]=\nabla F_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)\right), and 𝜽m1​(t)=𝜽​(t)superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑚1𝑡𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}^{1}(t)=\boldsymbol{\theta}(t). 𝒈m​(t)≜−η​(t)​∑i=1τ∇Fm​(𝜽mi​(t),ξmi​(t)),m∈[M].formulae-sequence≜subscript𝒈𝑚𝑡𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏∇subscript𝐹𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑚𝑖𝑡𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\displaystyle\boldsymbol{g}_{m}(t)\triangleq-\eta(t)\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{\tau}\nabla F_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}^{i}(t),\xi_{m}^{i}(t)\right),\quad m\in[M]. Device m𝑚m transmits a sparsified version of the local model update Δ​𝜽m​(t)=𝒈m​(t)Δsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑡subscript𝒈𝑚𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}(t)=\boldsymbol{g}_{m}(t), denoted by 𝒈^m​(t)subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t), m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. Upon receiving 𝒈^m​(t)subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t) from K𝐾K devices in ℳ​(t)ℳ𝑡\mathcal{M}(t), the PS updates the model as follows:

𝜽​(t+1)=𝜽​(t)+1K​∑m∈ℳ​(t)𝒈^m​(t).𝜽𝑡1𝜽𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑚ℳ𝑡subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}(t+1)=\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)+\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{m\in\mathcal{M}(t)}\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t). (28)

To simplify the analysis, we assume that each participating device has the same link capacity. This can be guaranteed through the resource allocation technique given in (14). For further simplification, we consider the following sparsification scheme. Each device sparsifies its local model update in a random fashion; that is, at iteration t𝑡t, it sets all but q​(t)𝑞𝑡q(t) entries, selected uniformly at random, to zero. Then, it quantizes the remaining entries using a 323232-bit uniform quantization scheme. It is easy to verify that each device needs to transmit

r​(q​(t))=log2⁡(dq​(t))+33⋅q​(t)​ bits,𝑟𝑞𝑡subscript2binomial𝑑𝑞𝑡⋅33𝑞𝑡 bits\displaystyle r\left(q(t)\right)=\log_{2}\dbinom{d}{q(t)}+33\cdot q(t)\mbox{ bits}, (29)

where q​(t)𝑞𝑡q(t) is set as the largest integer satisfying r​(q​(t))≤nm​Cm​(t)𝑟𝑞𝑡subscript𝑛𝑚subscript𝐶𝑚𝑡r\left(q(t)\right)\leq n_{m}C_{m}(t), for some m∈ℳ​(t)𝑚ℳ𝑡m\in\mathcal{M}(t), with nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m} given in (14).

We denote the set of all possible sparsity patterns of 𝒈^m​(t)subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t) by 𝒮𝒮\cal S, where |𝒮|=(dq​(t))𝒮binomial𝑑𝑞𝑡\left|\mathcal{S}\right|=\binom{d}{q(t)}, ∀mfor-all𝑚\forall m, and define ρ​(t)≜q​(t)d≜𝜌𝑡𝑞𝑡𝑑\rho(t)\triangleq\frac{q(t)}{d}. We note that, once K𝐾K and the quantization scheme are fixed, ρ​(t)𝜌𝑡\rho(t) is an i.i.d. random variable whose distribution depends on the channel distribution.

Due to random sparsification, the sparsity pattern of each model update follows a uniform distribution. Thus, we have

V-B Convergence Result

We assume that the device scheduling is uniformly random across the devices, which is consistent with the device scheduling policies introduced in Section IV. Thus, the probability that a device is scheduled for transmission at any iteration is KM𝐾𝑀\frac{K}{M}.

Theorem 1.

Let 0<η​(t)≤min⁡{1,1μ​τ}0𝜂𝑡11𝜇𝜏0<\eta(t)\leq\min\left\{1,\frac{1}{\mu\tau}\right\}, ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t. We have

𝔼​[‖𝜽​(t)−𝜽∗‖22]≤(∏i=0t−1A​(i))​‖𝜽​(0)−𝜽∗‖22+∑j=0t−1B​(j)​∏i=j+1t−1A​(i),𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽22superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖0𝑡1𝐴𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽0superscript𝜽22superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑡1𝐵𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖𝑗1𝑡1𝐴𝑖\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\Bigg{(}\prod_{i=0}^{t-1}A(i)\Bigg{)}\left\|{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(0)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\sum_{j=0}^{t-1}B(j)\prod_{i=j+1}^{t-1}A(i), (35a)
where
A​(i)≜≜𝐴𝑖absent\displaystyle A(i)\triangleq 1−μ​ρ​(i)​η​(i)​(τ−η​(i)​(τ−1)),1𝜇𝜌𝑖𝜂𝑖𝜏𝜂𝑖𝜏1\displaystyle 1-\mu\rho(i)\eta(i)\left(\tau-\eta(i)(\tau-1)\right), (35b)

Corollary 1.

From the L𝐿L-smoothness of function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot), after T𝑇T global iterations, we have

𝔼​[F​(𝜽​(T))]−F∗≤𝔼delimited-[]𝐹𝜽𝑇superscript𝐹absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F(\boldsymbol{\theta}(T))\right]-F^{*}\leq L2​𝔼​[‖𝜽​(T)−𝜽∗‖22]𝐿2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽𝑇superscript𝜽22\displaystyle\frac{L}{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}(T)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]
≤\displaystyle\leq L2​∏i=0T−1A​(i)​‖𝜽​(0)−𝜽∗‖22+L2​∑j=0T−1B​(j)​∏i=j+1T−1A​(i),𝐿2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖0𝑇1𝐴𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽0superscript𝜽22𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑇1𝐵𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖𝑗1𝑇1𝐴𝑖\displaystyle\frac{L}{2}\prod_{i=0}^{T-1}A(i)\left\|{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(0)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{L}{2}\sum_{j=0}^{T-1}B(j)\prod_{i=j+1}^{T-1}A(i), (36)

where the last inequality follows from Theorem 1. Having a decreasing learning rate limt→∞η​(t)=0subscript→𝑡𝜂𝑡0\mathop{\lim}\limits_{t\to\infty}\eta(t)=0, it is easy to verify that limT→∞𝔼​[F​(𝛉​(T))]−F∗=0subscript→𝑇𝔼delimited-[]𝐹𝛉𝑇superscript𝐹0\mathop{\lim}\limits_{T\to\infty}\mathbb{E}\left[F(\boldsymbol{\theta}(T))\right]-F^{*}=0.

Remark 2.

For a limited T𝑇T value, it is hard to clearly discuss the impact of ρ​(i)𝜌𝑖\rho(i) on the final average loss, since it depends on the other parameters, μ𝜇\mu, L𝐿L, M𝑀M, K𝐾K, ΓΓ\Gamma and G𝐺G. However, since A​(i)𝐴𝑖A(i) reduces with ρ​(i)𝜌𝑖\rho(i), one can observe that the convergence speed increases with ρ​(i)𝜌𝑖\rho(i).

Remark 3.

The first term in B​(i)𝐵𝑖B(i), which is due to device scheduling, is a decreasing function of K𝐾K, where we note that ρ​(i)𝜌𝑖\rho(i) reduces with K𝐾K due to resource sharing. Thus, B​(i)𝐵𝑖B(i) reduces with K𝐾K, and K=M𝐾𝑀K=M minimizes B​(i)𝐵𝑖B(i). On the other hand, since A​(i)𝐴𝑖A(i) increases with K𝐾K, which is due to the reduction in ρ​(i)𝜌𝑖\rho(i), the impact of K𝐾K on the convergence performance is complicated. We will observe in Fig. 3 that for different setting parameters different K𝐾K values provide the best convergence performance. However, when the resources are abundant such that ρ​(t)=1𝜌𝑡1\rho(t)=1, ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t, it is trivially known that the full devices participation scenario, i.e., K=M𝐾𝑀K=M, provides the best performance; this is corroborated by the result in Corollary 1, where, for ρ​(t)=1𝜌𝑡1\rho(t)=1, ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t, K=M𝐾𝑀K=M gives the best performance.

Remark 4.

Similarly to ρ​(i)𝜌𝑖\rho(i), the impact of τ𝜏\tau on the convergence rate is complicated. From A​(i)𝐴𝑖A(i), it is clear that the convergence speed increases with τ𝜏\tau, which verifies the observations made in [25], where increasing the number of local model updates is proposed to increase the convergence speed. On the other hand, B​(i)𝐵𝑖B(i) increases with τ𝜏\tau, limiting the value of τ𝜏\tau providing the best performance. We highlight that the last term in B​(i)𝐵𝑖B(i) reflects the impact of bias in the data distribution on the convergence rate. It is obvious that a higher τ𝜏\tau value would intensify the deterioration of this term on the convergence rate.

VI Numerical Experiments

Here we compare the performance of different scheduling policies for image classification on the MNIST dataset [26] with 600006000060000 training and 100001000010000 test samples. We train a multi-layer perceptron neural network with a single hidden layer with 256256256 parameters, in which case the total number of parameters is d=203530𝑑203530d=203530, where softmax is utilized as the activation function of the output layer.

We consider two data distribution scenarios: in the IID case, data samples at each device are selected at random from the training set; while in the non-IID case, each device has samples from only two labels/classes chosen randomly, and half of the local data samples are selected at random from each chosen label/class. We utilize ADAM [27] and AdaGrad [28] optimizers to train the neural network for the IID and non-IID data distribution scenarios, respectively.

For the experiments, we consider M=40𝑀40M=40 devices, each with B=1000𝐵1000B=1000 training data samples. For the transmission of the local updates, we assume n=5×103𝑛5superscript103n=5\times 10^{3} symbols available at each global iteration, and we assume a noise variance of σ2=1superscript𝜎21\sigma^{2}=1, and average power constraint P¯=1¯𝑃1\bar{P}=1. We set the number of local iterations at the devices to τ=3𝜏3\tau=3. We measure the performance as the accuracy with respect to the test samples, called test accuracy, versus the iteration count at the PS, t𝑡t. For numerical experiments, we consider the proposed D-SGD quantization scheme since it leads to a better accuracy than the random sparsification technique introduced for the convergence analysis.

In Fig. 1, we compare the performance of different scheduling policies for the IID data distribution scenario. The goal here is to find the value of K𝐾K resulting in the best performance for each scheduling policy. To this end, we consider two different values, K=1𝐾1K=1 and K=10𝐾10K=10, for each scheduling policy, where for BC-BN2 we set Kc=10subscript𝐾𝑐10K_{c}=10 and Kc=20subscript𝐾𝑐20K_{c}=20, respectively. We observe in Fig. 1 that, for each scheduling policy, increasing K𝐾K deteriorates the accuracy in terms of both the convergence speed and the final accuracy level. We did not include the results for other K𝐾K values, as we have observed that the performance of each scheduling policy deteriorates with increasing K𝐾K. Thus, we focus on K=1𝐾1K=1, which, based on our observations, provides the best performance for each policy. This illustrates that, with IID local data samples, sending a more accurate update from a single device (which is scheduled at random thanks to the symmetry across the devices in our model) provides a faster convergence rate in the long-term than sending less accurate updates from multiple devices. For comparison, we provide the final accuracy level of each scheduling policy for K=1𝐾1K=1. These are given by 91.2%percent91.291.2\%, 91.7%percent91.791.7\%, 92.3%percent92.392.3\% and 93.1%percent93.193.1\% for BC, BN2, BC-BN2 and BN2-C, respectively. As can be seen, BN2-C provides the best performance in terms of the convergence speed as well as the final accuracy level. The improvement of BC-BN2 over BN2 is marginal, but both outperform BC. These results illustrate that, given IID data distribution, scheduling devices according to both the significance of their model updates and their channel conditions provides gains in terms of accuracy. Also, from the superiority of BN2 over BC, we conclude that, to obtain the best performance for the IID scenario, the significance of the model updates, captured by the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of the local model updates, plays a more important role in the accuracy performance than the channel conditions. On the other hand, for large K𝐾K, such as K=10𝐾10K=10 (which does not provide the best performance in this experiment), it is important to consider the channel conditions for scheduling in order to make sure that the scheduled devices can send sufficient information about their local updates, rather than scheduling the devices based only on the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of their model updates.

In Fig. 2, we investigate the performance of these different scheduling policies for the non-IID scenario. As can be seen, for all the scheduling policies, unlike in the IID case, scheduling a single device results in instability of the learning performance appearing as fluctuations in their accuracy levels over iterations. In the non-IID scenario, the local model update at each device is biased due to the biased local datasets, and scheduling a single device provides inaccurate information and causes instability in the performance in the long-term. On the other hand, increasing K𝐾K (sharing resources among more devices) reduces the accuracy at which the scheduled devices can transmit their model updates. As a result, it is expected that a moderate K𝐾K value would provide the best performance, which is confirmed with our simulation results. For the setting under consideration, K=10𝐾10K=10 provides the best final accuracy for BC, BC-BN2 and BN2-C, while K=5𝐾5K=5 performs better for BN2, although K=10𝐾10K=10 shows a more stable accuracy performance with a higher final accuracy level. Similarly to the IID scenario, we observe that it is essential to consider the channel conditions for higher K𝐾K values in order to make sure that the devices can transmit enough information. Also, as can be seen from the performance of BC for K=10𝐾10K=10, when scheduling based only on the channel conditions, the performance is more unstable, unless a relatively large number of devices are scheduled, in which case the accuracy level deteriorates. We highlight that, compared to the channel conditions, scheduling based on the significance of the model updates has a greater impact on the performance at the initial iterations when the gradients are more aggressive. On the other hand, it is important to consider the channel conditions at later iterations when approaching the optimum solution, since the SGD algorithm is more vulnerable to the noise compared to the initial iterations, and a more accurate estimate of the model update at each participating device is required for robust communication against the noise. For comparison, the best final accuracy levels for BC, BN2, BC-BN2 and BN2-C are 78%percent7878\%, 77.5%percent77.577.5\%, 81.5%percent81.581.5\% and 81.7%percent81.781.7\%, respectively. It can be seen that BN2-C and BC-BN2 outperform BC and BN2 in terms of the accuracy level, highlighting the importance of scheduling devices based on both the channel conditions and the model updates at the devices for the non-IID scenario.

Next we investigate the convergence result, presented in Corollary 1, for various K𝐾K values. We consider two data distribution scenarios, where (Γ,G)∈{(1,1),(10,10)}Γ𝐺111010(\Gamma,G)\in\{(1,1),(10,10)\}. The case with larger ΓΓ\Gamma and G𝐺G values models a relatively more biased or less symmetric data distribution, in which case both ΓΓ\Gamma and the variance of the gradient at each device are expected to be larger.

The convergence results for different K𝐾K values, K∈{1,3,5,10,15,20}𝐾135101520K\in\{1,3,5,10,15,20\}, when M=100𝑀100M=100 are simulated for (Γ,G)=(1,1)Γ𝐺11(\Gamma,G)=(1,1) and (Γ,G)=(10,10)Γ𝐺1010(\Gamma,G)=(10,10) in Fig. 3(a) and Fig. 3(b), respectively. We assume σ2=P¯=1superscript𝜎2¯𝑃1\sigma^{2}=\bar{P}=1, n=105𝑛superscript105n=10^{5}, μ=1𝜇1\mu=1, L=5𝐿5L=5 and ‖𝜽​(0)−𝜽∗‖22=500superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽0superscript𝜽22500\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}(0)-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}=500. We set τ=3𝜏3\tau=3 and η​(t)=1000μ​τ​(t+1000)𝜂𝑡1000𝜇𝜏𝑡1000\eta(t)=\frac{1000}{\mu\tau(t+1000)}, ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t. We observe in Fig. 3(a) that, for smaller ΓΓ\Gamma and G𝐺G values, in which the data distribution across the devices is expected to be more symmetric and less biased, scheduling a single device, i.e., K=1𝐾1K=1, provides the best performance. On the other hand, the results in Fig. 3(b) illustrate that, for larger ΓΓ\Gamma and G𝐺G values, i.e., more biased data distribution, more devices should be scheduled to achieve the best average loss. As can be seen in this figure, K=1𝐾1K=1 provides the best convergence speed, slightly faster than K=3𝐾3K=3. However, K=1𝐾1K=1 has a much higher average loss than K=3𝐾3K=3, K=5𝐾5K=5 and K=10𝐾10K=10. Also, although K=3𝐾3K=3 provides a slightly faster convergence speed, K=5𝐾5K=5 achieves a smaller average loss. The convergence results demonstrated in Fig. 3 corroborate the experimental results shown in Figures 1 and 2; that is, when the data is distributed in a more symmetric fashion, such as in the IID scenario, all the resources should be given to a single device, whereas for a more biased data distribution, such as the non-IID scenario, a fraction of devices should share the resources in order to achieve the best performance.

In Fig. 4 we investigate the impact of the number of local iterations τ𝜏\tau on the convergence rate. We again consider two scenarios (Γ,G)=(1,1)Γ𝐺11(\Gamma,G)=(1,1) and (Γ,G)=(10,10)Γ𝐺1010(\Gamma,G)=(10,10), where the former models a more symmetric data distribution while the latter corresponds to a more biased data distribution, and, based on the observations made in Fig. 3, we set K=1𝐾1K=1 and K=5𝐾5K=5, respectively. We consider τ∈{2,3,5,10,15,20}𝜏235101520\tau\in\{2,3,5,10,15,20\}, and for fairness we set η​(t)=100020​μ​(t+1000)𝜂𝑡100020𝜇𝑡1000\eta(t)=\frac{1000}{20\mu(t+1000)} in all the simulations, which satisfies η​(t)≤min⁡{1,1μ​τ}𝜂𝑡11𝜇𝜏\eta(t)\leq\min\{1,\frac{1}{\mu\tau}\}. We assume σ2=P¯=1superscript𝜎2¯𝑃1\sigma^{2}=\bar{P}=1, n=105𝑛superscript105n=10^{5}, μ=0.25𝜇0.25\mu=0.25, L=5𝐿5L=5 and ‖𝜽​(0)−𝜽∗‖22=500superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽0superscript𝜽22500\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}(0)-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}=500. For (Γ,G)=(1,1)Γ𝐺11(\Gamma,G)=(1,1), we observe that increasing the number of local iterations τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 to τ=5𝜏5\tau=5 significantly improves the convergence performance in terms of both the convergence speed and the final average loss. However, by further increasing τ𝜏\tau the improvement in the convergence speed reduces, and the final average loss increases slightly, which is due to the relatively small asymmetry in the data distribution. This shows that, for a fixed local dataset with limited size, performing an excessive number of local iterations might not help to converge to the optimal solution faster even for a fairly symmetric data distribution. Similarly, for (Γ,G)=(10,10)Γ𝐺1010(\Gamma,G)=(10,10), the convergence speed, as well as the average loss improve significantly increasing for τ=5𝜏5\tau=5 compared to τ=1𝜏1\tau=1. However, it is evident that increasing τ𝜏\tau to τ=15𝜏15\tau=15 and τ=20𝜏20\tau=20 deteriorates the performance in terms of both the convergence speed and the final average loss value. As expected, designing an efficient τ𝜏\tau value is more crucial for a more biased data distribution, and increasing τ𝜏\tau excessively might cause divergence, since the local datasets do not provide a reliable representation of the whole dataset.

VII Conclusions

We have studied FL under limited power and bandwidth resources considering block fading channels from the devices to the PS. We have considered orthogonal digital transmissions from the devices to the PS, and studied various scheduling algorithms to decide which devices participate in the learning process at each round. There is a natural tradeoff between the number of devices participating and the fraction of resources allocated to each device. With more devices scheduled for transmission, the global model parameters are updated at the PS by utilizing a larger fraction of the training data samples; while, each device provides a less accurate estimate of its local model update due to the limited resources available per device. We have proposed novel device scheduling algorithms that consider not only the channel conditions of the devices, but also the significance of their local model updates. We have also established convergence result for FL over power-and bandwidth-limited wireless networks with device scheduling, which, to the best of our knowledge, provides the first convergence result in the literature for the setting under consideration. Experiments on the MNIST dataset have shown that it is beneficial to schedule devices based on both their channel conditions and the significance of their model updates rather than considering only one of the two metrics. Also, the best number of participating devices for each considered policy depends on the type of data distribution across devices; for an IID scenario, it is better to schedule a single device, whereas for a non-IID scenario, scheduling a moderate number of devices provides the best performance. The observation on the best number of scheduled devices for IID and non-IID data distribution scenarios is corroborated by the convergence result, where the asymmetry in the data distribution, which corresponds to non-IID scenario, is introduced by increasing the variance of the local gradients.

Appendix B Proof of Lemma 2

To prove Lemma 2, we take similar steps as [23, Appendix B.4]. We have

Appendix C Proof of Lemma 3

We have

𝔼​[‖𝝊​(t+1)−𝜽∗‖22]=𝔼​[‖𝜽​(t)+1M​∑m=1M𝒈^m​(t)−𝜽∗‖22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝝊𝑡1superscript𝜽22𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽𝑡1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡superscript𝜽22\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{\upsilon}(t+1)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\bigg{[}\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)+\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\bigg{]} (53)
=𝔼​[‖𝜽​(t)−𝜽∗‖22]+𝔼​[‖1M​∑m=1M𝒈^m​(t)‖22]+2​𝔼​[⟨𝜽​(t)−𝜽∗,1M​∑m=1M𝒈^m​(t)⟩].absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽22𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡222𝔼delimited-[]𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]+\mathbb{E}\bigg{[}\left\|\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2}^{2}\bigg{]}+2\mathbb{E}\left[\langle\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*},\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t)\rangle\right]. (54)

The convexity of ∥⋅∥22\left\|\cdot\right\|_{2}^{2} results in

𝔼​[‖1M​∑m=1M𝒈^m​(t)‖22]≤1M​∑m=1M𝔼​[‖𝒈^m​(t)‖22]=(a)ρ​(t)M​∑m=1M𝔼​[‖𝒈m​(t)‖22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡221𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡22(a)𝜌𝑡𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝒈𝑚𝑡22\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\bigg{[}\left\|\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2}^{2}\bigg{]}\leq\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\mathrel{\overset{\makebox[0.0pt]{\mbox{\tiny(a)}}}{=}}\frac{\rho(t)}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t)\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]

2​𝔼​[⟨𝜽​(t)−𝜽∗,1M​∑m=1M𝒈^m​(t)⟩]≤−μ​ρ​(t)​η​(t)​(τ−η​(t)​(τ−1))​𝔼​[‖𝜽​(t)−𝜽∗‖22]2𝔼delimited-[]𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript^𝒈𝑚𝑡𝜇𝜌𝑡𝜂𝑡𝜏𝜂𝑡𝜏1𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽22\displaystyle 2\mathbb{E}\left[\langle\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*},\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\widehat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{m}(t)\rangle\right]\leq-\mu\rho(t)\eta(t)\left(\tau-\eta(t)(\tau-1)\right)\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]
+ρ​(t)​(1+μ​(1−η​(t)))​η2​(t)​G2​τ​(τ−1)​(2​τ−1)6+ρ​(t)​η2​(t)​(τ−1)​G2+2​ρ​(t)​η​(t)​(τ−1)​Γ𝜌𝑡1𝜇1𝜂𝑡superscript𝜂2𝑡superscript𝐺2𝜏𝜏12𝜏16𝜌𝑡superscript𝜂2𝑡𝜏1superscript𝐺22𝜌𝑡𝜂𝑡𝜏1Γ\displaystyle\;+\rho(t)\left(1+\mu(1-\eta(t))\right)\eta^{2}(t)G^{2}\frac{\tau(\tau-1)(2\tau-1)}{6}+\rho(t)\eta^{2}(t)\left(\tau-1\right)G^{2}+2\rho(t)\eta(t)(\tau-1)\Gamma
+2​ρ​(t)​η​(t)​1M​∑m=1M∑i=2τ(Fm∗−𝔼​[Fm​(𝜽mi​(t))])+2​ρ​(t)​η​(t)​(F∗−𝔼​[F​(𝜽​(t))]).2𝜌𝑡𝜂𝑡1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑚𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐹𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑚𝑖𝑡2𝜌𝑡𝜂𝑡superscript𝐹𝔼delimited-[]𝐹𝜽𝑡\displaystyle\;+2\rho(t)\eta(t)\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\sum\nolimits_{i=2}^{\tau}\left(F_{m}^{*}-\mathbb{E}\left[F_{m}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}^{i}(t))\right]\right)+2\rho(t)\eta(t)\left(F^{*}-\mathbb{E}\left[F(\boldsymbol{\theta}(t))\right]\right). (65)

Plugging (C) into (56) completes the proof of Lemma 3.
